comments.commentBody: You must be a blast at parties.

Glenn,
Please try to enjoy life - or at least have an understanding of what others may enjoy - you will live longer, and happier.

I wish I could get a pay check for doing nothing.  If came to work and couldn't perform I would be let go so to speak. There sure wouldn't be a fat check waiting for me. So much money is wasted during the Super Bowl. It's none of my business how you spend your money. I hope you went to the game and I hope you donate at least what it cost you to go to the game to some charity that's in need ? This country is need and last I checked football didn't do a thing to help with the world's situations. But the Super Bowl did cause New Jersey tax payers a lot of money to have state troopers and cities road department ready in case of a snow storm. And to provide security. Too much money spent on foolish things.
You are forgetting TWO championships for the Seattle Storm.
The Seattle Storm won the WNBA Championship in 2004 and 2010, but they're just girls, right?
The 12th Man fans are the best in the world AND First major sports championship for Seattle in 35 years

MTF, the article itself is interesting, but the lists themselves don't embiggen very much.

A SPREE de CORK

We all at some time or other see a word in a puzzle and we love it.

Outside of puzzles, I have a fondness for Monegasque. And Glaswegian. Who else has favorites?

Here, a famous author shares some of his favorite words. (Thanks to the Twitter Feed on the Public Editor blog page for this.)

http://www.openculture.com/2014/01/david-foster-wallaces-lists-of-his-fa...
How about some respect. Lemme guess, east coast far.  Don't need you. Never will. Have fun cheering to sup par teams
Three classes when you include the single payer Medicare. Maybe four if you include the VA.
We need a single payer plan that just not game the system.

Dr. K,

I would like to add to your list of false claims made by the opponents of Obamacare & then comment on fixes to Obamacare that should be made,

A vexing criticism I have heard about Obamacare is it has lowered the earning of Americans by forcing companies to cut the number of hours of compensation per week by employers because if the employees work more than 30 hours, the employer would be required to provide health insurance.

The objective of Obamacare is to (1) provide better health care to Americans, (2) reduce the cost of insurance for Americans, & (3) reduce the cost of healthcare delivery.

It seems to me that a single plan should have been offered to all Americans. Gaming the risk pool with bronze, silver, etc was a mistake, It was fashioned after the terribly unfair health insurance industry. Remember the fundamental principle of "insurance" is the larger the pool the lower the "risk cost" to each of the members.

Obamacare is a step forward by (1) limiting the commercial insurance carriers to a fixed percentage of administrative costs. The next step as soon as the opponents get their heads right and Americans appreciate the benefits is "Medicare for All" & bring more discipline to payments for healthcare (2)eliminating "cherry picking" & denying treatment for pre-existing conditions.

I am very optimistic that Obamacare will be improved. I don't like the Medicaid concept because it establishes a 2 class society & we don't need any more of that.

The 10,000 deductible does not resolve the free rider problem of the individual who declines to pay for insurance and then is unable to pay for care.   You would need to require those individuals opting for a high deductible to post a bond for medical expenses they intend to cover from their own resources.  That would be even more complicated.  Better to require insurance like we do for automobiles.

Except health insurance is not the way normal insurance works. Normal insurance leaves the individual with the ultimate loss, perhaps others due to bankruptcy if that subsequently occurs.

In health insurance, the taxpayer is still left holding significant portions of the bill because we don't deny health care in the "catastrophic" events.

So, the people skipping paying on insurance are in fact exploiting you the taxpayer. Think that's a fair choice?
Why not?
PLEASE, logic.

Why not?  (How does one say this respectfully) - If the "No GMO" is an emotional response, it is completely valid, but impossible to debate.  If the "No GMO" is an intellectual response, then it is also a valid response, but is now a response that is possible to discuss.
PLEASE, no GMO wheat.
From Omaha Omaha to Oh My God Oh My God.

There may have been only 7,000 of the 12th man in the stadium so we all had to be 10 times as loud. If Peyton Manning had played us at our home field, every snap would have looked like that. We have a deaf fullback. Denver might want to check into that!

The first play of the game, a bad snap from the center resulting in a 2-pt safety for Seattle, was an omen for the rest of the game. It was caused by bad communication between Manning and the center because Manning was calling an audible (changing the play at the line of scrimmage) and jumping around. That seemed to cause the center to misunderstand Manning's intentions. Throughout the game, Manning seemed to be calling his own plays at the scrimmage line. Didn't work out too well for Denver.

There is a football adage that goes "live by the blitz, die by the blitz." There should be another one that goes, "live by the audible, die by the audible."
I don't see any of those kinds of comments here. Did you also predict that the Broncos would win?
You are forgetting TWO championships for the Seattle Storm.
Since currently 25% of corporations pay no tax - the real entitled moochers, I doubt we would notice any difference under your proposal.

@Ozark Homesteader:"I'd add reform to the corporate tax code. Any company that fell within the 20:1 compensation ratio would pay zero corporate taxes. The worse your ratio, the higher the corporate taxes."

I've argued for years that the most natural and easy-to-manage reform of this nature is to phase out deductibility of executive compensation as the ratios get out of whack. Since these overpaid CEOs justify their bloated comp packages by juicing share values in the short term, there would be inherent shareholder pressure to keep profits up by retaining maximum deductibility.

In short, make excessive compensation no longer a business expense, and corporate earnings (and thus the value that the market puts on shares) will be less. Less earnings, because Mr. Executive Suite rakes in eight figures instead of a mere three or four hundred times what his average worker does, and listen for the howls from the shareholders.

Excellent proposal but you need to consider not just wages but total compensation, since some executives have a $1 salary but other compensation that is outrageous.  I'd add reform to the corporate tax code.  Any company that fell within the 20:1 compensation ratio would pay zero corporate taxes.  The worse your ratio, the higher the corporate taxes.  Sure, we'd lose a bit of corporate revenue but make up for it in higher personal income tax and payroll taxes from workers.

I think Jane Roberts is more than a little bit off when she says gender inequality the "moral scourge of our age." In the 19th century, women in China had to contend with having their feet bound; In 21st Century America, 60 percent of our college students are female. That's part of why Christine Quinn Lost in New York and why Hillary is old news.

That said, I must laud the main article for its important contribution to the discussion of inequality. I have often thought that inequality and psychopathology were positively correlated, but this article augments my thought with evidence.
An alternative view, failure of state exchanges proves what Americans already new, government has no business running the nation's healthcare.

A large reason America's costs are greater is because we fund a large amount of the ongoing research in HealthCare. There are a variety of economic studies which show a system which charges the rich more (and yes all Americans are rich compared to the majority of the world) and the poor less allows the greatest amount of innovation and development.

Now there are a lot of problems in the system in general, but this general principle helps explain a significant part of the cost.

I think you are supporting the argument in the article.  WalMart and Costco target the most price conscious buyer.  Sears and J.C. Penny have historically tried to attract a more affluent customer.  Costco sells clothes in piles on tables, J.C. Penny has a Jones of NY line and Sears has Lands End products.

Try again. Unemployment has been high, so how has the middle not suffered. I have never been on unemployment my whole career until this crash, I'm 55! As to Sears and JC, yeah they haven't adapted well. But lets keep in mind that Walmart workers are the biggest group of people that are on food stamps with very little of them receiving healthcare, nice business model for the tax payers. Don't count out the articles comments on the restaurants.

There is a significant difference in the quality of clothing for sale at WalMart and JC Penneys, just as there is considerable difference in the quality of Penney's and Nordstroms.  Just today I was thinking of the poor quality of clothing at Kohls and Macy's and grousing to myself about it.  What I do now is wait until clothing at Dillards goes on sale, if a need something.  Or I check out the local thrift store where I can occasionally find good quality second-hand stuff.  Those of us in the middle class still appreciate quality.  We just can't afford it anymore.

"Since 2009, the year the recession ended, inflation-adjusted spending by this top echelon has risen 17 percent, compared with just 1 percent among the bottom 95 percent."

This is misleading. During the bust before 2009, most likely it was the spending by the top echelon that fell the most, and that explains the rise afterward. As to Sears and JC Penney, well, Wal Mart and Costco are doing great. One can't just pick only the failing stores to make the point.
Rather than praying, we need to fight them.

Republicans aren't all delusional, Paul.

Some of them are callous liars. Their concern with Affordable Care and attempts to fix healthcare system centers on vast sums of money.

My wife and I had dinner last evening with close friends; the husband has made his living for decades in the healthcare field, now consulting hospitals and care companies around the U.S., Canada, and in the U.K.

We talked about Affordable Care for awhile and his opinion was, I'll paraphrase him, that it's about time. He quoted some widely acknowledged statistics about waste in our system and excessive cost and boldly asserted, not for the first time, that as an example of waste, in general American physicians make a way too much money.

See the NYTS:
http://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/15/how-much-do-doctors-in-othe...

http://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2013/02/charts-day-doctor-pay-amer...

Of course, our cost and spending is income for a powerful, wealthy group who contribute generously to Conservative causes and hire lobbyists to make sure nothing changes.

When Republicans in our House vote to repeal Affordable Care, they aren't just joshing us. Given the slimmest chance, they will do in D.C. what has happened in State governments turned over to Republicans: roll back the clock of progress to approximately the Gilded Age.

They'd get rid of Civil Rights, Title Nine, and other acts, too, if they thought their power allowed it.

Pray it doesn't.
.

Retailers who're losing in heated competition -Red Lobster, Penny's, Sears- blame the greater economy. The business world wants to take the esdy wsy out,  selling overpriced merchandise to people who're too busy or snooty to care.
I agree honeybee, those are not the best examples to highlight a declining middle class. They are bad restaurants getting their due. The main point of the article still stands, however.

Though I don't doubt the middle class is shrinking/having a harder time getting by due to inflation, ridiculously rising college tuitions, I agree with you there about those particular food and clothing businesses.

I don't know how much 'Omnivore's Dilemma', Alice Waters' Slow Food movement, public awareness of alarming levels of obesity and backlash against the Fast Food Nation culture, have contributed to the decline of Red Lobsters and Olive Gardens, but I suspect they have more influence than the shrinking middle class as this article describes.

Also, rise of social media, and the availability of product reviews on almost everything on the internet, would spread awareness of any poor quality product faster than word of mouth. I suspect companies cannot repeatedly get away with selling crap to the masses, using conflict raw materials from warlord run countries and third world sweatshops, as easily as they used to in this day in age.

I think business declines are actually due to the poor quality of products and service.
The simple truth is that people now would rather stay home than pay a penny for low-quality food, run-down motels or clothes pulled out of a pile on a table.
Red Lobster's or Olive Garden's problem is its food, service model and atmosphere, not a missing middle class.

I think you miss the point. Your imaginary sales floor sounds like Glengarry Glen Ross and not like a kind of world where most of us want to live. A hyper-competitive, hyper-capitalist environment where my sales-peers and I fight tooth and claw, month-to-month, over sales quotas, while religiously accepting that the top guys are our betters, to whom we are not worthy to compare ourselves? Swell. In your rush to explain why the poor should never raise their eyes to their betters, you just described a pretty perfect recipe for depression, narcissism, and toxic mistrust.

Most of the rest of us just want to do a good job at our work, take pride in what we do, and go bowling on the weekends. We're more numerous and more moral, but we're getting trampled by the people who think of the sales floor as a perfect metaphor for how society functions.

These days $30K is not enough to make ends meet.  The problem is constant worry over $ and never having enough of the basics, juggling one debt to pay another and having to constantly tell the kids no to everything.  Living in cramped quarters.  Making the kids feel inferior to friends at school . . . This starts really young & we learn quickly that we have a limited place at the table.  Why do most Americans say that they are middle class when by any economic measure they are not?

I think you're all missing my point.  I was replying specifically to the thrust of the article, which sought to add a psychiatric dimension to the political debate.   An exec making 30 million probably is as close to an explanation of someone's depression as the planet Pluto is to Earth.  If you can't show a causal link between depression among the middle or poorer classes and the wealthy, you haven't made your case.  A depressed middle class person may not like income disparity or even think it's fair.  But I don't think this article succeeds in making the case that clinical depression - in whole or in part - results from that disparity.  There are many possible reasons for higher levels of depression in high income states, and you can argue that some of that depression is among those with high incomes themselves.  And by the way, I stand by my sales organization analogy as regards the importance of peer groups in understanding income-related depression.  In sum, most of these comments seek to make political points rather than address the article itself.

Surely no one is depressed over making only $30,000 yearly because some corporate exec is making $30 million. Most of us don't travel in those circles, and don't likely make that comparison - or conclude that someone else's success is the reason for our own more modest means. The depression you write about, to the extent you can show a causal relationship rather than merely correlation in the pattern you discuss, most likely relates to peer groups. If I'm living in a middle class neighborhood and just lost my job at the same time my neighbor got a promotion, I might feel depressed and inadequate. We tend to compare ourselves to those around us who are in roughly similar circumstances. If our inner difficulties result from unsuccessful social climbing in Greenwich Ct., or in other wealthy states as you seem to suggest, well, don't blame the president of IBM.

For an apt comparison, look at sales organizations. Lower level producers don't generally compare themselves to top producers. They compare themselves to those around their own level. When a sales peer has a good month and they don't, they feel depressed. Their sense of self worth is diminished. But they feel no remorse over a top producer who beats the pants off them every month. Lower level producers expect that, and assign no blame nor feel any animus toward top producers.

I suggest we're all better off keeping psychiatry out of the income tax debate.

I see a lot of correlations here, but surely cause and effect is inverted here.  Is it so far-fetched to propose that status-oriented dominant narcissists create highly unequal societies, which is a bummer for the rest of us?  They even bum themselves out.  It's a social dynamic, and money is only one dimension of it.   Oh, I get it.  It's not the 1%ers' fault that they are such jerks!  They have "Affluenza."  See?  Their money made them do it.  Not Their Fault.  Riiiight.

It's never happened before. The Republican party feeds their worldview, sense of victimization, bigotry, need for security of authority and rigidity, religion based ideas, and ignorance. When all the port cities are underwater and farm areas turned into deserts in a few decades they will not figure anything out but just go on to the next lie.

I hope, but doubt, that I will live to see this prediction become even 50% right.
There are bigots all over the world who still refuse to believe that Nelson Mandela was a man of exceptional intelligence, integrity, and moral courage. The same can be said about Ghandi, and Dr. King.

@fschoem44: You're probably right, but MLK, etc. never hit these nitwits in the pocketbook - at least directly. Money talks to them; their own money even louder so. Someone will calculate the global extent of the loss and publish it. And that's usually the point when the legal profession comes sniffing and agitating.

As I'm fond of quoting DH Lawrence: "Let's upset the apple cart; and see which way the apples go a-rolling." Let's see about political fealty when someone realizes that this sewer of deceit cost them their life savings.

It has occurred to me - and likely Ms. Grenier's isn't alone in her refusal to use "that Obama website" - that an entire cohort of the population, counting perhaps something less than 49% of voters, doesn't care if it's being deceived.

The right wing obsesses like raving paranoiacs that they're being deceived by Mr. Obama, though statistics and facts rarely if ever bear out the sources of their suspicions. Yet when their own party openly and without shame tells childish lies that subvert their quality of life directly and dearly, GOP supporters can't be more glad for being deceived. (I'd call that the final word in craziness.)

But what happens - and it will happen - when the deceived wake up to recognize the depth of deception; not only on healthcare, but foreign policy, the environment, education, inequality.

Being oblivious out of spite eventually gives way to the shock of reality: how many will wake up bamboozled and what will be the total financial hit for all that lying about ACA? One fine day, the GOP, caught by its own public record of planned deceits - more obvious and more foolish than the covert strategies of the cigarette industry - will be handed one of the biggest class action suits in history.

It might take a while, but the Republican Party will suffer the wages of stupidity. Americans have taken corporations to court for less.

Agree with your statements 're' need for soul searching; we seem to be living in a society were what we have defines us better that who we are, to our shame. And once we live in the stratosphere of influence and affluence, our social distance becomes a huge barrier to compassion, and to feel for our fellow men, and 'to be able' to respond to the needs of others, to know that what we have comes from others (hence, should be shared more equally). Otherwise, we remain an empty shell that just happens to be sitting on a useless pearl.

True.  If you are not eligible for Obamacare then you get tp pay a huge deductible and a hefty monthly premium.  It's more like purchasing catastrophic insurance. That is not health care.  Single Payer is the ONLY alternative!

I took 5 minutes to check "that Obama website" and guess what? I can choose a plan with a $12,700 deductible if I want to. Once again, someone hears a focus-group-tested talking point, mistakes if for fact, and ends up spreading the talking point.
Full disclosure: this applies in the state of Texas, for a family of two. If someone wants to do a fact-check on Washington state, please do.
If she loved the policy she bought, then GOP is even more vile than we thought. If she liked it, why was she complaining about it to Ms. Morris-Rogers? Just to kvetch?

Have you never considered that Ms. Grenier and her husband made the choice to have a huge deductible, a choice that is no longer available to them?

C.J. Roberts had it right, this law is akin to taxation. If we had a single-payer system in place it would make sense, but to force people to fork huge sums of money over to health insurance for-profit corporations is just plain wrong.

Jane of Alexandria is right. Without the public option, many people will have reduced choices. This should be one of those 'tweaks' that can be fixed to make Obamacare better. It was irresponsible of the Democrats to cave on this one.

I wonder what is going to happen when the
March 31 deadline passes, and millions of people, it turns out, have decided not to buy insurance. This
would surely be interpretable as a type of "heroic" large scale civil
disobedience/protest that will serve to galvanize
millions of voters in November...with significant consequences for control of the Senate etc...

Some of that interpretation will be standard rightwing media spin, but would all of it be?

This idea must surely already be percolating and marinating in the red-state mindset blogosphere...as a type of
rallying cry and badge of honor for the "hero rebel mindset"...

Has anyone run across this yet by those
with the stomach to follow such sites?
